description: Estimate and evaluate limits using graphical and numerical approaches

coreConcepts: lim(x→a) f(x) from tables of values
When limits don't exist (oscillation, unbounded, disagree)
teachingTips: Tables first, then graphs, then algebra
Use open circles on graphs to build intuition
AP exam tests this on nearly every MCQ section

description: Evaluate limits using factoring, rationalizing, and simplification

commonMistakes: Dividing by zero without recognizing indeterminate form
teachingTips: 0/0 is a signal to do algebra, not an answer
Build a decision tree: try substitution first
lim sin(x)/x = 1 must be memorized

description: Evaluate one-sided limits and identify vertical asymptotes through infinite limits

coreConcepts: Limit exists iff both sides agree
commonMistakes: Writing lim = ∞ instead of DNE for two-sided
Sign errors in infinite limit analysis
Confusing infinite limits with limits at infinity
teachingTips: Piecewise functions for one-sided practice
Sign charts near vertical asymptotes
Clear notation: lim = +∞ or -∞

description: Evaluate limits as x → ±∞ and identify horizontal asymptotes

coreConcepts: Same degree: ratio of leading coefficients
teachingTips: Divide by highest power of x
Leading term shortcut for polynomials
Most commonly tested limit type on AP exam

description: Determine continuity at a point and classify discontinuities

coreConcepts: Three conditions: f(a) defined, limit exists, limit = f(a)
Continuous functions: polynomials, trig, exp, log on domains
teachingTips: Test all three conditions systematically
Piecewise functions with parameters are classic AP problems
Connect to IVT hypotheses

description: Apply Intermediate Value Theorem and Squeeze Theorem

coreConcepts: IVT: continuous on [a,b], k between f(a) and f(b) → f(c)=k exists
Using IVT to prove existence of zeros
Squeeze theorem: if g(x) ≤ f(x) ≤ h(x) and lim g = lim h = L, then lim f = L
commonMistakes: Not verifying continuity before applying IVT
teachingTips: IVT is tested on FRQ — practice writing complete justifications
Squeeze theorem mainly used for special limits
State hypotheses AND conclusion

description: Compute derivatives using the limit definition (difference quotient)

coreConcepts: Derivative as instantaneous rate of change
Derivative as slope of tangent line
commonMistakes: Not canceling h before taking limit
teachingTips: Work through x², x³, √x, 1/x by hand
Both forms appear on AP exam — recognize both
Connect to secant line → tangent line visually

description: Determine where functions are differentiable and understand the relationship with continuity

coreConcepts: Corners, cusps, vertical tangents, discontinuities → not differentiable
Left and right derivatives must agree
teachingTips: |x| at 0 is the canonical example
x^(2/3) for cusp, x^(1/3) for vertical tangent
Piecewise with matching derivatives at junction

description: Apply power, product, quotient, and sum/difference rules

teachingTips: Power rule must become automatic
Product/quotient need consistent practice
Rewrite radicals and fractions as powers first

description: Differentiate trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions

coreConcepts: d/dx[sin x]=cos x, d/dx[cos x]=-sin x
d/dx[tan x]=sec²x, d/dx[sec x]=sec x tan x
d/dx[ln x]=1/x, d/dx[log_a x]=1/(x ln a)
commonMistakes: Sign errors with cos and csc derivatives
teachingTips: Memorize the table cold
Derive trig derivatives from sin/cos via quotient rule
e^x being its own derivative is the defining property of e

description: Estimate and interpret derivatives from graphical and tabular data

coreConcepts: Derivative ≈ slope of tangent ≈ [f(b)-f(a)]/(b-a) for nearby points
Reading slope signs from graph of f
Sketching f' from f and f from f'
Interpreting derivative in context (rate of change)
commonMistakes: Using too-wide intervals for table estimates
Not interpreting units in context problems
teachingTips: This is the most tested non-algebraic derivative skill
Practice sketching f' from various f graphs
Always include units when interpreting

description: Differentiate composite functions using the chain rule

coreConcepts: Chain rule with trig: d/dx[sin(3x²)] = cos(3x²)·6x
teachingTips: 'Derivative of outside, leave inside alone, times derivative of inside'
Most important rule — used in every subsequent unit
Verbalize the steps until automatic

description: Find dy/dx for implicitly defined functions

coreConcepts: Differentiate both sides with respect to x
Every y-term gets multiplied by dy/dx (chain rule)
commonMistakes: Product rule errors with mixed x·y terms
Substituting values before solving for dy/dx
teachingTips: Circle y-terms to remember dy/dx
Practice with circles, ellipses, and mixed-variable equations
Essential prerequisite for related rates

description: Differentiate inverse functions including inverse trig

commonMistakes: Not applying chain rule with arcsin(2x) etc.
teachingTips: Derive using implicit differentiation
arctan is the most commonly tested inverse trig derivative
Table-based problems: given f and f' tables, find (f⁻¹)' at a point

description: Solve problems involving rates of change of related quantities

coreConcepts: Identify all variables and known rates
Write an equation relating the quantities
Differentiate implicitly with respect to t
commonMistakes: Forgetting the chain rule (dy/dt, not just dy)
teachingTips: Always draw a diagram and label
Write 'Given:' and 'Find:' before anything else
Classic problems: ladder, balloon, cone, shadow, Pythagorean

description: Analyze motion using derivatives and interpret velocity/acceleration

coreConcepts: Speeding up: v and a same sign. Slowing down: opposite sign
commonMistakes: Not using absolute value for speed
teachingTips: Use number line diagrams for sign analysis
Connect to physical experience
This returns in integration (Unit 8)

description: Approximate function values using tangent line linearization

coreConcepts: Tangent line as best linear approximation near a
teachingTips: Classic: approximate √(26) using linearization at x=25
Concave up → underestimate, concave down → overestimate
Tested on MCQ and FRQ

description: Evaluate indeterminate limits using L'Hôpital's Rule

coreConcepts: Applies only to 0/0 or ∞/∞ indeterminate forms
lim f/g = lim f'/g' (differentiate separately, not quotient rule)
May need to apply multiple times
commonMistakes: Applying quotient rule instead of differentiating separately
Not verifying form before each application
teachingTips: Always write 'form: 0/0' before applying
Can sometimes use algebra instead (factoring may be faster)
AP includes this in AB — students must know it

displayName: Mean Value Theorem & Extreme Value Theorem
description: Apply MVT and EVT with proper justification

coreConcepts: EVT: continuous on [a,b] → absolute max and min exist
MVT: continuous on [a,b], differentiable on (a,b) → f'(c) = [f(b)-f(a)]/(b-a)
MVT geometric meaning: tangent parallel to secant
teachingTips: MVT shows up on FRQ nearly every year
Always state: 'Since f is continuous/differentiable...'
Practice writing complete MVT justifications

description: Use first derivative to find intervals of increase/decrease and local extrema

coreConcepts: Critical points: f' = 0 or f' undefined
First Derivative Test: sign change at critical point
Candidates Test for absolute extrema on [a,b]
teachingTips: Sign chart of f' is the primary tool
Candidates Test: critical points AND endpoints
Justify with calculus language on FRQ

description: Use second derivative for concavity, inflection points, and Second Derivative Test

coreConcepts: f'' > 0 → concave up, f'' < 0 → concave down
Inflection point: concavity changes (f'' changes sign)
Second Derivative Test: f'(c)=0 and f''(c)>0 → local min
commonMistakes: f''=0 does NOT guarantee inflection (must change sign)
Not connecting f'' sign to f behavior
teachingTips: Concave up = 'holds water' = 'smile'
Moving fluently between f, f', f'' graphs is critical for AP
Second Derivative Test is faster but less reliable (inconclusive when f''=0)

description: Sketch and analyze function behavior from derivative information

coreConcepts: Full analysis: domain, intercepts, asymptotes, critical/inflection points
teachingTips: Practice both directions: f→f' and f'→f
This is the synthesis skill for Unit 5
AP MCQ frequently gives graph of f' and asks about f

description: Find maximum/minimum values in applied contexts

coreConcepts: Reduce to single variable using constraint
Find critical points, test for max/min
teachingTips: Draw a picture, label everything
Write 'Maximize:' or 'Minimize:' explicitly
Classic: fencing, box, distance, can problems

description: Approximate definite integrals using Riemann sums

teachingTips: Build from tables first (AP loves table-based Riemann sums)
Connect to area under curve visually
Increasing → left under, right over

description: Apply both parts of FTC to evaluate and differentiate integrals

coreConcepts: FTC1 with chain rule: d/dx[∫ₐᵍ⁽ˣ⁾ f(t)dt] = f(g(x))·g'(x)
Connecting differentiation and integration as inverses
commonMistakes: FTC1: forgetting chain rule with variable upper limit
Not recognizing FTC1 in disguised forms
teachingTips: Both parts tested extensively on AP exam
FTC1 with g(x) upper limit is an FRQ favorite
FTC2 is how you actually evaluate definite integrals

description: Find antiderivatives using basic rules and recognize common forms

coreConcepts: ∫sin x dx = -cos x+C, ∫cos x dx = sin x+C
commonMistakes: Power rule: add 1 and divide (reverse of derivative)
teachingTips: Reverse the derivative table
Always check by differentiating
+C represents the whole family of antiderivatives

description: Integrate using u-substitution (reverse chain rule)

coreConcepts: Let u = inside function, find du
Substitute, integrate in terms of u, back-substitute
Definite integrals: change bounds to u-values
commonMistakes: Forgetting to adjust for constants in du
Not changing bounds for definite integrals
teachingTips: Most important integration technique for AB
Look for function and its derivative together
Check by differentiating the result

description: Sketch and interpret slope fields for differential equations

coreConcepts: Slope field shows dy/dx at each (x,y) point
Sketching slope fields from dy/dx formula
Drawing solution curves through given points
commonMistakes: Inconsistent slopes at same y or x
Solution curves that cross slope segments
teachingTips: Nearly guaranteed MCQ topic
Look for where slopes are 0, positive, negative
Solution curves follow the flow

description: Solve separable DEs for general and particular solutions

coreConcepts: General solution (+C) vs. particular solution (use IC)
Solve for y explicitly when possible
commonMistakes: +C on wrong side or both sides
teachingTips: Step 1: separate. Step 2: integrate. Step 3: +C. Step 4: apply IC
Practice with y' = ky first (exponential model)
FRQ often asks for particular solution with initial condition

description: Model growth/decay scenarios using differential equations

coreConcepts: Half-life: t = ln(2)/|k|, doubling time: t = ln(2)/k
teachingTips: Connect to precalculus exponential models
Real-world: population, radioactive decay, cooling
AP FRQ gives verbal setup → student writes and solves DE

description: Compute and interpret the average value of a function on an interval

coreConcepts: Geometric: height of rectangle with same area
MVT for Integrals: f(c) = f_avg for some c
commonMistakes: Confusing with mean of discrete values
teachingTips: Simple formula, tested in context
Must interpret what the average means
Often paired with FTC in context problems

description: Use integrals to find displacement, distance, and net change

commonMistakes: Not using absolute value for distance
teachingTips: Split at zeros of v(t) for total distance
Net change theorem = FTC2 in word form
Most common FRQ application of integration

description: Find area enclosed between two curves using integration

coreConcepts: Breaking into sub-regions when top/bottom switch
teachingTips: Always sketch first
Identify which function is on top in each region
With respect to y can simplify certain problems

description: Find volumes using known cross-sectional areas

commonMistakes: Not identifying the side length from the base region
teachingTips: Draw the base region, then draw the cross-section
Side of cross-section = top function minus bottom function
AP loves this problem type

description: Find volumes of revolution using disk and washer methods

coreConcepts: Revolving around lines other than axes
Choosing between disk/washer and dx vs dy
commonMistakes: Wrong R and r when revolving around non-axis line
teachingTips: Draw the cross-section (disk or washer) at a sample x
R = distance from axis to outer curve, r = distance to inner
Revolving around y=k or x=k: adjust R and r by subtracting k
